segments.text: This is an interview with Louis Antoine Truart.
The date is the 20th of April, 1985.
How old were you during the years 1940 to 1945?
Fourteen.
Where were you in the years 1940-1945?
In Nice, France.
How long after France fell to the Nazis in 1940 was it before you became involved in the resistance?
Well, quite a few years, because we moved from Lyon, where we used to live, down to Lourdes, which is on the border of Spain and France.
And then at that time, I was just nine years old, and they flipped the coin between my mother and her friend, if we should stay in France or go to Spain.
and the coin came down and we stayed in France.
So we stayed in France.
We stayed in Lourdes for quite a while, because France was divided.
The northern part was occupied by the Germans, southern part was still free.
The Italians were supposed to take over, but they didn't.
And then we moved from Lourdes to Marseille, and then from Marseille to Nice.
So you ended up in Nice in what year?
We ended up in this in 1943.
Is that when you became involved with the resistance?
Right after 1944, yeah.
What part of the resistance were you in?
What did you do?
Sabotage.
Okay, great.
Did your role change or did you stay in sabotage the whole time?
I stayed in sabotage and stealing weapons.
Do you know who the head of your area of resistance was?
By code name Manley.
Did you ever find out who it really was?
After the war, yes.
After the war.
What was the code name and who was the person?
Beer Man.
Beer Man?
Yeah.
And who was, what was his real name?
What was the question?
What was his real name?
Oh, I forget.
That's 40 years ago.
I don't remember.
That's okay.
He was a sales representative for the beer distributor in that area of Nice.
And we sell beer to the German and got friendly with them and talk, you know, and get information from them, that's all.
But his code name was the Beer Man.
But you didn't know who he really was until after the war?
No, until after the war, yeah.
Okay, great.
Did you ever talk to your family about what you did or what they did, or did you see things that they did?
Well, very likely because
The way things were going, you know, you didn't know who your friends were, even in your family.
And a lot of time in some of the family, some of the parents or kids turn against each other.
And so we talked very little bit, although we knew what we were doing.
We knew what my mother was doing, trying to get those Jew to escape from France to Spain, back to England.
But that's about the extent of it.
Very, very little bit.
The less you knew and the better off you were.
Just do your job and that was all.
So your mother participated in the resistance too?
Very strongly, yes.
And what did she do?
Some transportation?
Did she do any intelligence?
She was mainly information, gathering information from the German...
I don't know what you call them, the German that...
supply ammunition to the front line.
They have a special name, and I forget what it is now in German, but whatever.
She was trying to make them talk, be very friendly with them so that we knew their move, so we could go ahead and get in the middle of it and stop them.
Did you ever help her with these conversations, try to get it out of them?
No, she just did her own, you know, and she...
We invited a German officer.
They were real nice.
We had a lieutenant.
He was a German-Russian.
His name was Lupankov.
P-A-N-K-O-V is his name.
A Russian, but a white Russian.
And he was very mean, but he was very talkative, you know.
I mean, we invited him.
I mean, my mother invited him.

feed him and give him wine and beer, kind of trying to mix things up so he could turn information loose, you know, and then say, hey, why don't you come up next Friday, you know, and we'll have a barbecue party or something like that.
And he said, well, no, I can't because I'd have to be out of town.
And I said, oh, come on, you can get somebody else to do it.
He said, no, we have to take a whole triangle of ammunition in such and such place.
And that's all we needed.
So we turned that to the underground and blew the train up.
So we were pumping information.
For me, we never realized that's where it came from.
And your mother turned that information over?
We turned that over to a man that was the head of the Red Cross in Nice.
We didn't know his name, but we knew he was a Red Cross man.
That's all.
And he was a Frenchman?
Oh, yeah.
OK.
What were some of the special codes that help you to identify other people in the resistance?
Did you know codes that would just, a general code that would help you know somebody was in the resistance, or did you just have codes that you worked with in your own little group?
No, we just, we were, in our particular area, we didn't know no more than six people through a code deal, and any one of the six knew six more.

So we couldn't, if we get caught, you know, and beat on to it, you know, to talk, we wouldn't give no more but just six people's name, code name, which really don't mean nothing to the German because it was not their real name.
Did you have a code name?
Yeah.
What was it?
I had two.
One was the American.
They called me the American.
The other one, Mac.
They called you the American?
But for a long time after the war, you know, all my friends called me Mac.
It was not my name, Louis H., who I had nothing to do.
They call me Mac.
They see me in the street, say, hi, Mac, how are you doing?
Okay.
That was just one of those names that just hang on with me.
Huh.
But the other one, the American, that was the one in touch with the beer man.
Oh, huh.
That's the only way we come in the UK.
Beer man, American, won't talk to you, and that was it.
If I give any other name, he won't see me.
If I say I'm Mac, forget about it.
Did you have a special code that meant certain things, like one sentence would mean, I have to go do this, or we need to do this, or get out of here, the Gestapo's coming?
Oh yes, definitely.
Could you give me some examples?
Not really.
We had code that was given to us through the beer man, telling us when to get a certain place, you know, like...
if they were going to drop something from the airplane for us to use for sabotage purpose, then they had a code name saying that Robespierre will shave himself six times.
That meant that we were going to look for six parachutes.
They were going to send some stuff for demolition purpose.
Or the last one we had was the car are going down the cellar.
That man, you guys better hide out because D-Day is coming up.
They're really going to drop it on you.
And that was some of the code name, some of the code word we had.
Do you know where the beer man got his codes?
From the head of that particular area, which I knew after the war, you know, who she was.
It was a lady.
What was her name?
Emily Jet Latouche.
She was the aunt...
of the chief of police of the city of Nice in France, which at that time was about 250,000 people.
But you didn't know her name at the time?
Oh, no.
Did you know her code name?
No.
I didn't know her at that time at all.
So if you got any code changes, they came from the beer man.
Right.
That was the head of our group.
How did you know that if that man was going to shave six times, how did you know what that meant?
We listened to that through... Oh, okay.
The beer man knew some of the code that was given to him 24 hours prior to down on the radio, shockwave radio.
They had a shockwave radio somewhere.
And all those codes, they were fresh code.
And...

If they had that twice on the radio, then the Germans were trying to do the same thing, trying to come back with the same type of code, trying to confuse us, but we knew that was not it, because it was always a new code, and they knew the code name.
And it happened that the German government radio, you know, and gave some false signal trying to catch some of the people, but it didn't work.
They never did.
How did you know it was the Germans?
Because you use a colonel one time, that's it.
After the rest, dead.
And they never caught on to that fact?
Well, they didn't know what's going on, you know, right then.
What specific jobs did you do?
And you can tell me about a few of the most important things that you did or the most outstanding.
Well, sabotage and then police.
plastic charge on the bridge, you know, just get the stuff ready for the people who knew what they were doing.
In other words, they give us a bunch of little bag that had sugar or sand in it.
And we were to crawl over the fence where they had all those tanks and the German Jeep and the truck parked.
And they had a bunch of German Shepherd turn loose in the place.
Well, we got friendly with them by giving, throwing them some meat.

and then we used to go to those vehicles and drop those back in the fuel tank taking the cap off put them back in the tank you know and then when they start to drive the vehicle it jammed the engine you know just get the diesel pump all messed up and they just break down and then the underground just jump on the top of them and took care of them so they were just
And then the other part of it was a plastic bomb.
You know, the sticky bomb you put under a bridge to blow a bridge up.
What we did is just stuck the stuff under there and then let the other guy take care of the charge and blow up the bridge.
So you just made sure that he had everything he needed to work with.
Yeah, we just stick the thing under, you know, that big black thing, go over there and stick it under that part of the bridge.
So we just go over there, you know, and the Germans wouldn't know who it was.
You know, we'd just see kids playing.
They didn't think that we were...
doing harm, and we were just sticking that stuff.
And they were dynamite charged.
Of course, we were kids, we didn't know about it.
If we knew, we'd probably put the thing over there.
But that's what we were doing.
You know, they were using us.
We didn't know what we were doing.
But you knew it was to win the war.
Yeah, it was to get rid of the bad German.
We had some good German, but it was to get rid of the bad ones.
Okay, I talked about the beer man a few minutes ago, and what we were doing, we were sending beer to Germany because they like beer, you know, like I do.
And we used to sell them beer, and then we'd collect an empty bottle.
So we used to go in the room, and when they were not there, when they were gone, doing their business, you know, out of town, and then if I see any weapons, hand grenade, gun, or...
We didn't try to steal machine gun or rifle, but mainly pistol and hand grenade.
Then I used to collect those and give them to the beer man so we could use them against the Germans.
So that was lots of time.
I used to go downstairs, four flights from the hotel with about six or seven hand grenades in my belt and two or three pistols.
and didn't know what I was doing with it, but I would take it to the bear man and give it to him, and in turn, he'd give it to the right people, you know, to use.
So that's... Did you work by yourself, or were there other kids that worked with you, or was that too dangerous?
No, the bear man didn't want nobody to, nobody else to be involved with.
We were a single unit.
If you get caught, you couldn't give nobody else names.
to the Gestapo, that's all.
Were you asked to pick up small arms when you collected beer bottles?
Or did you kind of do that on your own at first?
No, they didn't ask anything so that if I was caught in trial, they could say that they asked me to do that.
They said, do whatever you think is the best to do for your country.
So we went ahead and took everything we could find, except the big thing that you couldn't hang, hide, you know, like a rifle.
You can put that in your pants, you know, so...

anything that's small enough like hand grenade pistol so we use it dynamite lots of dynamite took quite a bit of dynamite did you get your beer bottle route so that you could steal things or did it just happen to come along that was settled by beer man so he just set me up he knew where i was supposed to go but he didn't tell me that you know he just said you go there and there and collect and that's it four or five different hotels
So in other words, he really did kind of set you up for the job, but you decided whether or not you wanted to take the arms at that particular time.
Well, he knew what he was doing, and I didn't know any better, so I just wanted to do the job.
All right.
Did you know that D-Day was coming?
Yeah, we were aware of it.
Did you know specifically when?
Did they give you a date, or just in a few days, or...?
They give us a...
signal that it was going to happen, no date and no place of whereabouts.
But we knew that when they come up with a word through the BBC that it was time for us to get ready for it.
So you got all your information through the BBC?
That's correct.
Were there any special actions that you or the group of people you knew of did to prepare for D-Day?
Yes, at that particular time
They say, when you hear a certain message through the BBC, then you say, at that time, go ahead and collect all you can from the Germans.
That's handgun, machine gun, whatever you can, even if it's a big weapon.
And then sabotage everything they have, like putting those little bags, whatever they had in it, sand or sugar, into all their tank, truck, and motorcycle.
and just go and dump everything, just get rid of it, to create a panic with the Germans among themselves.
So we knew that when that happened, that was it.
Do that and then get out of the way because they'll be mad, they're gonna shoot everybody inside.
So we did.
Do you remember what the message was that you got from the BBC?
Do you remember how it sounded, the words?
Yeah, it was which means that the car will go down to the cellar.
It was time for us to get down there and hide.
We were the cow.
Go down there and hide.
Okay.
Did you particularly have any special assignment?
You were just trying to pick up all the arms and stuff.
Yeah, we did.
The last thing I did is pick up a German Luger out of the officer's room.
It was a 9mm Luger.
And I gave it to the beer man himself.
He came by, you know, and I gave it to him.
And I know that with that Luger, he shot a guy out of a motorcycle.
He just put him out of business.
So that was the end of it.
Were you aware of all the other jobs that the resistance was doing, the intelligence, the transportation?
No, all that was kept secret.
Nobody knew what the other hand was doing.
But did you know kind of in general that it was happening?
We knew that the whole machine was rolling, but for protection among each other in case we get caught by the Gestapo.
They wouldn't tell you anything, what one figure was doing to the other finger, you know.
We just, you knew your own job and that's it.
And you had nobody else but six people that you knew right around you.
And each one of the six knew six other and that's it.
And they all had code names.
So we didn't know no name to speak of it, except recognize a face.
Were you aware of the ongoing arrests and execution of resistance members?
And if so, how did you deal with your own danger?
Well, I was too young to worry about that, you know.
Yeah, we were aware of some of the Germans catching some of the people my age, stealing guns, and then put their hand on the board and cut their hand with an axe.
Just chopped the hand right off of it.
And that we had, I had several, not several, I had a few friends that either where they had their hand chopped off or they had their feet chopped off.
and just flat cut their feet with an axe.
Goodness.
Just as a punishment.
Do you know anybody that worked with the resistance that had or has psychological problems like recurring nightmares, nervous breakdown, that type of thing?
I have one friend, just one that I know, I forgot his name now, but he was, when the Germans caught him, the Gestapo caught him, they gave him to a,
a kind of a experiment lab where they were injecting kerosene in his blood and studied the reaction.
And after the war, he was crippled to a point that he couldn't walk.
And he could, but he was really dragging himself like he had polio.
And he became very ferocious.
And at the end of the war, he knew some of the people that had done that to him.
And he got the hold of what they call a Bok gun, which is a machine gun.
When you pull the trigger, it was somehow automatic.
And he shot a bunch of people that crippled him.
Some were French that turned him in.
And I remember one scene that I remember.
It was downhill from our place.
where he called one of the French guys that turned him in, and he told him, he said, and he turned around and just pulled the trigger and killed him right there with that machine gun.
And you saw it?
And I saw that, you know, and the guy just got killed right there.
Well, he deserved it, really, but that's some of the things that happened.
How old was that guy that got caught?
Well, he was in his 20s.
Oh, boy.
Were there any specific Nazi raids in your area, such as gathering the Jews up or flushing out the resistance, any major things that happened in your area?
Yeah, we had, my sister had a party for front of her birthday party, and usually the Germans didn't like for you to get together, you know, more than three or four people in one group.
The minimum you could get together was three.
And, but at that time we were such a good people with the German, they thought we were, you know, sending them beer and so that they okayed the party.
But we needed, they needed at that time a record player to play music.
So they weren't even borrowing that from the German.
And the German caught that, that friend of my sister, you know, and then, and those are the airplanes coming on top here.
an American airplane bombing France.
They caught him and asked him to strip down and expose himself.
They decided, well, either he's a Jew or he looks like a Jew.
So after quite a bit of talking, they decided, well, he belonged to the Truart, so he's a good guy.
They turned him loose.
But he was an American Jew.
He escaped real close.
Were you ever questioned by the Nazis or the Gestapo?
Yeah.
One time as a kid I was playing a soldier and it was an American soldier and my friend was a German soldier.
And I turned around and shot him.
And boy, the Gestapo gave me hell for that.
They took me in their house and put me in the dark room, and they said they were going to beat me and all that, but they were just scaring me, you know.
But I really felt strange, you know, at that time.
I bet.
I was just a kid, you know, playing, and I was a good old American soldier, you know, shot a German, you know.
Somebody had to be the American, end up to be the one, you know.
But that's about as close as I got to the Gestapo that I wanted to be close to it.
Did you think they really were going to beat you?
Well, I thought they were serious about their business, you know, but they were just trying to scare me as a kid.
Yeah.
Were you ever questioned by the French police?
No.
I was too young for that.
How did you feel about the French police, who seemed a lot of the time to help the Nazis locate members of the resistance?
They seemed a lot of times to be...
More for the Germans than for the French.

We had, just thinking about that now, I remember something that a friend of mine, well he was not a friend of mine, he was a school guy, he was about four years ahead of me, he was about 18, I was 14, and he was in one of those dime stores in France.
And I walk into that store, and I knew there was an underground guy that was being suspected by the Gestapo.
So I went over there to warn him and say, hey, look out, you got the, we call them the cousin German, you know, the German uncle, I mean cousin.
They asked you, get your butt out of here.
And that guy that I knew it,
There was a French guy, and he had a gun on him, and he was working for the Gestapo.
He was a traitor.
And I went to him, you know, and I said, oh, how are you doing?
He said, well, I'm on surveillance right now.
I'm watching that guy over there.
And that was the guy that I just told him to get out of there.
So I told him, I said, well, come on, let's go have a soda pop, you know, and we had ice cream.
And by that time, the other guy left.
And at the end of the war, that guy got shot, that collaborator.
We used to call him that...
Not through me, but somebody else had told me they just wanted to shot him.
No trial.
Do you know other people that collaborated with the Germans?
Oh yeah, our neighbor.
What did they do?
They gave it to one of the mothers and a sister.
They had a friend, he was a Jew.
They put him on the train, sent him to Lyon so he can go to Switzerland.
And they called the Gestapo.
At that time, you could get 500 francs for every people that you turn in for reward.
And they did so, you know, and they went ahead and turned him in.
He got arrested in Leon.
And those people, they were colored white there, but they died before the end of the war anyway, so we didn't have to shoot them.
They died of?
Old age.
You know, they just, about two years later, they were...
But they were on the list of the bad people.
They were our next door neighbor.
Oh, wonderful.
Were any members of your family ever question your sister or your mother that you know of?
No, not really.
No, they trust us too much.
We would play our game right.
Just that one time that your sister went to borrow the record player?
Right.
And then the time I played the American soldier.
About what percentage of the population in your area do you think were members of the resistance?
Well, we were kept in a blind spot, you know.
All we knew, like I say, is six people in our area.
We called the six men, that was it.
But I would say that probably 30 or 40 percent of the population was involved.
And the rest of it, they were too old to be involved in it.
The younger ones, they were on the underground in Germany.
Do you remember the names of the six people that you worked with?
Yeah.
One was an Armenian, and his name was Andrei Pekmezian.
That's his real name?
That was his real name, yeah.
What was his code name?
Do you remember?
Oh, no, I don't.
No?
And then the other one was... Oh, the other one was me.
That's two.
And then the other one...
We used to call him Hotel Riviera because he was the, his daddy was in charge of a big 200 room hotel next door to us.
And I don't really remember his name.
That's way over 40 years ago, but it's hopefully hard, you know, just two or three guys and that's it.
Do you know what happened to any of them?
Yeah, the only one that I know about is Andre Pecmesian.
He's on a gold resale business around the world.
He sells gold.
He buys and sells gold.
He's Armenian.
And he used to live in France, and that's what he's doing.
The other one's still in a business hotel.
He manage hotel, big hotel.
The same hotel?
Probably.

That hotel that I'm talking about, that Andre Pykmyshyn, not Andre Pykmyshyn but the other guy managed, that used to be the dump for the, what we call dump is where they put all the ammunition for the Germans.
They had bombs and rockets and dynamite and hand grenades and
And the ammo, just plain old rifle ammo, it was stacked up a mile high.
They dug a big hole in the ground and buried all that and then stuck it by the ground.
And then at the end of the war, they realized they couldn't carry that with them, so they blew the whole thing up.
And you talk about a big hole in that place.
I bet.
They just blew the whole thing and blew the roof out of our house and blew the roof of Henry Peck Maison's place out.
That's where we hide at the end of the war, in his house.
And that was quite an explosion.
They blew it up, or the Americans blew it up?
They did.
No, the Germans did.
They knew they couldn't carry it, so they went ahead and sabotaged themselves.
This was the Diamond D-Day?
That was the same day that the Americans were landing in the central page in southern France.
Did anything else happen in your city for the D-Day?
Yeah.
The French people got overexcited.
They didn't realize that the Americans were supposed to go towards Marseille, which is the opposite direction of Nice.
So they went ahead and liberated themselves.
Like we did, all that gun and rifle and hand grenade they stole from the Germans, got in the street and started to shoot the Germans, so the Germans took off.
They were overrun by 200,000 against maybe 10,000 Germans, so they took off.
But what we didn't realize is that they had that big armored train that was on track.
They had a big cannon, and they had ammunition and everything on the train, and they took that on the hill above the town.
And we were afraid that they were going to start to shoot the town, all the pieces.
So some of the underground got in touch with the American that landed in St. Lopez and told them, hey, we are free now, but the Germans are coming back to free us.
So they sent a colonel of GI to Nice to help us.
And they were showing off, you know.
When the Americans showed up, then the Germans really took off.
Even though there was just a handful of it, it was just, it demoralized them to see the Americans were there.
And if the Americans had to fight, they couldn't have fought because they were moving too fast.
The tank and truck and all that, when they're moving, the jeep, they were traveling 60 miles an hour.
Then the rest of the convoy didn't have a chance to catch up with it, but it played a real good...
deal on the German's mind, you know, saying, oh, well, you got the Americans, just keep it up, you know, forget about it.
What were the German people like?
What were the German soldiers like?
Oh, we had some real, real good guys.
We had two men that I really remember real well.
They were real good guys, and one still is, well, I guess he's died of old age by now, but one was, his name was Ludwig Gioff.
And the other one was Carl Berger.
And Carl got killed by the French communists, which were not part of our group.
They were another group that we didn't like, but they had done their own damage to France.
But Ludwigs Guiaf, we had him in our hotel at the end of the war, where we already had some American pilots that were hiding.
They were shot down, you know, so we told them, hey, just stay there, you know, this is the end of it.
Pretty soon the G.I.
will be over and you'll join your rank.
So when that officer came down the basement and saw those Americans, and he put his gun down and said, what the heck's going on here?
And we told him, we said, well, we had those...
American pilot for quite a while here, and we just couldn't, things were getting tighter, we couldn't turn them back to Spain, you know, and back to England, so we kept them over here.
So he just laughed, he said, well, I guess I'm your prisoner now.
So, but he was a real, real nice guy, and right now, well, at the end of the war, back in 1952, I was in Germany, and he had a restaurant over there in Saarbrck, and I met him over there again, and
I had quite a welcome.

He got me so drunk, I don't even know what the hell happened that day, but he really was pleased, you know, that what we did to him as a German officer, to the American, you know, save him from being shot.
And he was a real nice guy.
During the whole first phase of the war, they give us food and provide us with things that we needed.
The Germans themselves, they were not bad.
The ones who were bad were the Prussians, what they called the Gestapo, the Wehrmacht, the SS.
Those guys, they were terrible.
They'd shoot their own mother, their own sister.
They didn't care.
But the Germans themselves, they were good people.
I had no trouble with them at all.
They helped us quite a bit.
They helped me quite a bit.
How?
They fed me.
That's for sure.
They gave me food.
They split the ration, and they said, don't eat too, because if I said that I give you some of my food, they'll cut my food out, and then that's it, you know?
So I kept my mouth shut, just chewing on it.
You just mentioned something about taking the American pilots to Spain.
Do you know anything about the transportation routes of the Jews or the American pilots that got shot down?
Yeah, my mother was in charge of that.
At that time, I didn't know what she was doing after the war.
I realized what she did.
And what she did was she disguised those American pilot and copilot and gunner and whatever it was on the plane, give them women's clothes.
And then when the man from the Red Cross came with his van, panel truck, they load all those women aboard the truck and take them to Spain.
And then from Spain, they would get on a submarine and go to England.
And two of the people that she sent through there, one was a major.
I don't remember their name.
One was a captain, one was a major.
They're the one who gave our name to the American

the government, and in turn, they called my mother in Paris and give her a medal, and then they called me and give me a medal, and of course, I didn't care much about a medal, you know, but we got the medal anyway, and they told us anytime I want to come in this country, but we had the door wide open.
And did you, when you came here?
Well, I couldn't speak a word of English, and I didn't care to come over here, but I came here on vacation, and I'm still here, and that's what my boss says, still on vacation.
You haven't mentioned much about the plight of the Jews during this time, except for that one time for your neighbor.
Did you know anything about the gathering up of Jews, the transportation of Jews to the concentration camps?
Well, not a lot, no, other than the close friends that I had that were Jews.
I knew that some of them got caught in a...
They were put in a boxcar where they put cattle in it and packed them and sent them to Germany.
But we didn't keep track.
We couldn't keep track at that time.
Of course, we had no communication.
But we knew they had it.
Once they got on those trains, that was it.
Yeah.
Was there any specific place in your area where the Nazis took the Jews before they boarded the trains to go off?
Yeah, they had a house about a couple blocks down from our place.
They called it Villa de Nobilis.
And that was a center where they question and interrogate the suspect on the underground, all Jews, to get more Jews' names or more underground names.
And they had the SS and the Gestapo right there to do the interrogation.
And that house was known to be a torture house where they put you in the basement.

They had a post in the center of the room, and they'd strip all your clothes and make you walk around and around that post during the winter when it was real, real cold, and then trying to make you talk, and if you collapsed or fell down, they'd get a bucket of water and they'd just throw it at you and wake you up, you know, and knock you with a battle rifle, and you'd go again around the post until you'd talk or you'd die.
And they had on that house, after the war, I remember now,
a place, they had a bathroom where they used to submerge people, submerge their head in the bathtub full of water and then wait that you suffocated.
And then when you start to turn blue, I guess, you know, they pull out the water, give you artificial respiration, try to bring you up and then make you talk again.
And then telling you that you were dying.
And that was some of the good things that they were doing to you.
And the other
The only other thing that I remember is what they call the lead room.

It was a room that was fully, the walls were covered with lead, and they keep you in that room, and as you know, I don't know what it does to people, but they say it reacts to their physical, you know, they just...
Turned insane, you know, because there was no way out.
There was no air coming in, no nothing.
It was sealed completely.
That was the only type of insulation they had, solid lead.
So they just keep them in the room and keep those either Jew or underground guy, seal them in that room, you know, and then just wait, you know, peek through windows.
They had double window deal and see when the guy collapsed, you know, go in there and bring him back to life, make him talk and then turn him back into the room.
So those were the few places that they tortured people in that Villa de Nobilis.
What does that name mean?
It's just a name like Joe Brown or Frank Smith.
It was a name, an Italian architect that designed the house.
Way before the war, he had nothing to do with what happened to it.
Did you know anybody personally who were tortured in some of these rooms, or did you just hear stories or somebody that knew somebody?
No, we had a...
The head of the underground in our particular area, her name was, I guess I said that before, Emilie Jete Latouche.
She was the aunt of that chief of police in Lyon.
I mean, chief of police in Nice.
And she was in that house.
Did I mention that on the tape before?
Well, she was tortured, you know, and then the Gestapo came over and picked her up.
Okay, well, that's one of the people that I knew that went through that particular place right there.
And then there was another French Jew woman who went through there, but somehow she got free through some...
German mistake.
They turned her loose, you know, thought they had the wrong woman.
And they had the right one.
There's a bookkeeper mistake right there.
And Bo, she disappeared too.
I mean, they couldn't find her after that.
She got out of there and she just escaped.
And that's about it.
Okay, on that Villa de Nobilis I was talking about a few minutes ago.
That lady that we learned later on was the head of our underground, was of course Emilie Jete Latouche, and she was caught by the Gestapo.
They took her into that villa and then just go in and torture her, beat her up to death, you know, and just left her almost dead, you know.
And finally the

German Wehrmacht and the Gestapo came over to pick her up, take her to a correctional center where they would really start to cut on her finger and cut on her toe and then just cut the piece, you know, to make her talk.
They came over to pick her up.
So the German people in that villa turned loose to that Gestapo and the Wehrmacht

And the officer in charge of that particular group, there were five guys, just went ahead and knocked the heck out of her, you know, just put her on the ground and say, you think you had hell over here, you just wait until we give you our treatment.
We're going to start to cut your finger one at a time, you throw one at a time, you burst one at a time, you're going to talk.
And they loaded her in the car and then took off.
And that was the end of it because all those guys that were from the underground, they just free her up.
And the Germans were really upset about that, but the Germans that were supposed to come over and pick her up, they were all killed and bushed by those people.
So she was freed, and after the war, and of course she came through that, you know, and her nephew was the appointed chief of police for the city of Nice, and I knew him pretty well myself.
young friend of mine in school that was his nephew.
So it was kind of like a family deal.
Are there any other people that you know worked in the resistance and are now important people or still in the area there?
Okay, when we were in San Diego, we met, excuse me,
We had a, we met a friend in San Diego in California that was from France.
And he was in the underground in the Pyrenees.
His name was Maurice Richoux.
And the Gestapo caught him.
And to make him talk, they hang him by the foot.
And then when the blood come to his head, you know, when it got real red, purple, you know, they just went ahead and beat him up in the head, you know, trying to make him talk.
And he's, well, at that time he was in San Diego.
He was a tailor making a suit, a real good French tailor.
Did he have any problems from the beatings and stuff that he received that you could see?
Well, really he didn't have no problems.
the physical problem that you could see except that he was kind of a slow to react on question that you ask him.
His wife used to get mad at him, you know, and you ask him a question and it take him a while, you know, to go ahead and register and then give you an answer.
But that was due to the beating that he got, you know, and it just affect his brain, you know, just being hang upside down and went through all the blood get to your head and you get beat onto it.
I'm pretty sure done some damage to his
way of thinking after that.
Did you have any personal memories or problems that came about as a result of the war and your activities in the resistance?
Well, after the war, when everything was over with it, the American Free France, for many, many years after that, at night if I could, if I hear airplane flying, it used to scare me.
because I used to remember that all the flight that the British and American Air Force were doing over France was at night so they don't get shot.
So anytime I heard, anytime I could hear an airplane flying at night, it just scared me to death, you know.
And for a long, long time after I came in this country, night flight was just a nightmare for me.
I just stayed in the bed and listened to it and was waiting for the bomb.
And that's about it.
OK, something else I remember.
I remember when we were fleeing from the German.
They came through France.
We left Chaussin, which is in Jura.
We went through Lyon and southern France.
And we end up in the Pyrenees.
We had on the road, we were driving.
And you could see cars on each side of the road.
They were shot down by airplane, by German airplane.
And in our car, my mother was there, my sister, and Mr. Jean there, the friend of my mother and her daughter and myself.
And my mother had a little briefcase handcuffed to her hand where they were carrying all their gold.
It was full of gold.
We were taking that to Southern France.
And in the trunk, we had
everything we could salvage from the place, you know, that Mr. Jean did salvage, which was, it was champagne.
So we had champagne in the trunk, we had gasoline can in the car, and we had gold in the front seat.

And every time we could hear one of those planes coming above us, you know, he pulled under a big, tall tree, a poplar tree, you know, which are pretty tall, and you could hear the machine gun or the airplane trying to shoot us, you know, and we just wait there until he got tired of flying or run out of fuel, you know, and take off, and then we keep on going.
One thing that I remember, we used to, not we, but my mother and Mr. Jean, they used to trade some of the champagne for food and other need that we needed, like milk for us.
And we stopped into a small town and it was a dairy.
We stopped at a dairy, you know, and they needed some milk for us.
We asked the guy, they asked the guy, they says, hey, do you have some milk for the kid?
And he said, no, we don't have any milk anymore.
We just milked the cow about two hours ago and the milk is gone.
And he said, well, I got a bottle of champagne.
You'd like to trade that for a bottle of milk?
He said, hell yeah, we got the milk.
So he went over there and traded the milk for the champagne.
Do you feel that your personal contributions to the resistance were worth the danger?
Yeah, I felt that what I've done, you know, helped.

some or matter of fact helped quite a bit on our particular area that particular part of town in nice where we were involved with the german and especially with the munition people where they were taking the ammunition to italy and i felt a little bit i did you know help to free france just very little bit but every little bit count that's true well thank you very much for this interview
